sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1:
A math student wants to estimate the temperature of a certain location on a day based on the temperature readings taken at 4 different times of that day. The given temperature readings are: 

| Time (hours)| Temperature (°C) |
|-------------|------------------|
| 6           | 21               |
| 9           | 25               |
| 12          | 29               |
| 15          | 26               |

Using Lagrange Polynomial Interpolation, determine the estimated temperature of the location at 3:00 pm on the same day.
message_2:
To estimate the temperature at 3:00 pm (15 hours) using Lagrange Polynomial Interpolation, we will use the given data points (6, 21), (9, 25), (12, 29), and (15, 26). The Lagrange Polynomial is given by:

L(x) = f(x0) * L0(x) + f(x1) * L1(x) + f(x2) * L2(x) + f(x3) * L3(x)

where f(xi) are the temperature values and Li(x) are the Lagrange basis polynomials:

L0(x) = (x - x1)(x - x2)(x - x3) / ((x0 - x1)(x0 - x2)(x0 - x3))
L1(x) = (x - x0)(x - x2)(x - x3) / ((x1 - x0)(x1 - x2)(x1 - x3))
L2(x) = (x - x0)(x - x1)(x - x3) / ((x2 - x0)(x2 - x1)(x2 - x3))
L3(x) = (x - x0)(x - x1)(x - x2) / ((x3 - x0)(x3 - x1)(x3 - x2))

Now, we will plug in the given data points and the desired time (x = 15) into the formula:

L0(15) = (15 - 9)(15 - 12)(15 - 15) / ((6 - 9)(6 - 12)(6 - 15)) = 0
L1(15) = (15 - 6)(15 - 12)(15 - 15) / ((9 - 6)(9 - 12)(9 - 15)) = 0
L2(15) = (15 - 6)(15 - 9)(15 - 15) / ((12 - 6)(12 - 9)(12 - 15)) = 0
L3(15) = (15 - 6)(15 - 9)(15 - 12) / ((15 - 6)(15 - 9)(15 - 12)) = 1

Now, we will plug these values back into the Lagrange Polynomial formula:

L(15) = 21 * L0(15) + 25 * L1(15) + 29 * L2(15) + 26 * L3(15)
L(15) = 21 * 0 + 25 * 0 + 29 * 0 + 26 * 1
L(15) = 26

So, the estimated temperature at 3:00 pm (15 hours) is 26°C.
